## üå¶Ô∏è **Weather Data Scraper Automation**

This n8n automation helps you **scrape weather data from a website**, extract useful info, and **log it directly to a Google Sheet** ‚Äî great for personal dashboards, weather research, or historical weather tracking.

---

### üü¢ **SECTION 1: Start & Fetch Weather via Bright Data**

| ‚ö° Start Workflow                                          | üåê Request Weather                                     |
| --------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------ |
| ![Start](https://img.icons8.com/ios-filled/40/rocket.png) | ![Web](https://img.icons8.com/fluency/40/internet.png) |

#### üß© Node 1: `Start Workflow`

* **Type**: Trigger node
* **What it does**: Starts the automation manually or through a schedule.
* **For Beginners**: Think of this like the **"play button"** for your entire workflow. You can trigger it by hand or set it on a timer.

#### üß© Node 2: `Request/Fetch Weather via Bright Data`

* **Type**: HTTP Request
* **What it does**: Uses [Bright Data Proxy](https://brightdata.com) to send a request to a weather website and **fetch the full HTML page**, even bypassing bot protections.
* **For Beginners**: Bright Data acts like a smart assistant that **gets web pages without getting blocked**. It makes web scraping more reliable.

---

### üü† **SECTION 2: Extract & Process Weather Info**

| üß† Extract HTML                                         | üìã Log to Sheet                                             |
| ------------------------------------------------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------- |
| ![HTML](https://img.icons8.com/color/40/html-5--v1.png) | ![Sheet](https://img.icons8.com/color/40/google-sheets.png) |

#### üß© Node 3: `Extract Weather Info`

* **Type**: HTML Extractor
* **What it does**: Parses the HTML and **pulls out specific info** like temperature, humidity, and conditions using CSS selectors.
* **For Beginners**: Imagine this node as a **filter** ‚Äî it sifts through a huge webpage and pulls only the useful details you care about (like the current temperature).

#### üß© Node 4: `Log to Weather Sheet`

* **Type**: Google Sheets Integration
* **What it does**: Appends the extracted weather info into a Google Sheet ‚Äî creating a simple log or database you can review later.
* **For Beginners**: This is where all the magic gets stored! Each run adds a new row with the latest weather so you can build a **daily weather tracker**.

---

| ![Output](https://img.icons8.com/external-flat-icons-inmotus-design/40/external-Export-File-interface-flat-icons-inmotus-design.png) |

#### üß© Final Output: Weather Data Stored

* **What it means**: The Google Sheet now holds all the weather data you‚Äôve collected over time.
* **How to use**: You can:

  * Analyze trends üìà
  * Create dashboards üìä
  * Set up alerts for specific weather events (next step!)
  * Or just check how today compares to last week!

---

### üß† Summary (For Beginners)

> **In simple terms**:
> You click a button (or schedule it), it gets the weather from a website using a smart fetcher (Bright Data), pulls only the info you care about, and **stores it safely in Google Sheets**.
> It's like building your own **personal weather archive**, no coding needed!
